title: Projects without pipelines don't show vulnerabilities on the project security dashboard
description:
### Summary

Projects without pipelines have an error when the user visits the project's security dashboard.

![error on project security dashboard](/uploads/d54680b80230c51dc20b99df125f047e/image.png)

Note: this is an edge case that should only occur in development environments. In production, vulnerabilities are only created from pipelines, so this bug only occurs when vulnerabilities have been seeded manually.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a new project
2. In the Rails console, add a vulnerability to the project
3. Visit the project's security dashboard. You should see the error from the screenshot in the summary

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

The security dashboard fails to load the vulnerability list.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

The security dashboard loads the vulnerability list.

### Possible fixes

Update `ProjectsHelper#project_security_dashboard_config` to remove the reference to pipelines

title: Make "Filter by commit message" Input Consistent with Author Select
description: --- ## Background Information The following discussion from !28509 should be addressed: - [ ] @pedroms started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/28509#note_321293608): (+1 comment) > @sming-gitlab can we please make the two filters visible and full-width on smaller screens? title: Remove temporary "Vulnerability List" item from left-hand nav (under Security & Compliance menu item)
description:
### Problem to solve

<!-- Include the following detail as necessary:
* What product or feature(s) affected?
* What docs or doc section affected? Include links or paths.
* Is there a problem with a specific document, or a feature/process that's not addressed sufficiently in docs?
* Any other ideas or requests?
-->

The addition of the left-hand menu item "Vulnerability List" (under Security & Compliance) was added as a temporary measure to aid in our transition away from displaying findings on our Security Dashboard. Now that the Security Dashboard is backed by Standalone Vulnerabilities this menu item is redundant. Please remove this menu item. 

![image](/uploads/0928bfa6a1882be1a1299fc88c8d928f/image.png)


### Further details
There is a breadcrumb on the Standalone Vulnerability page that will need to be updated to point to the Security Dashboard page instead of the Vulnerability List page. Including this update in the scope of this issue but please split into its own issue if necessary. 

Ensure that this menu item isn't referenced in any documentation instructions or screenshots.

title: Do not remove users from a Group when enabling GMA
description:
# Problem

Our largest SaaS customer has expressed that is not at all desirable to have all of their users removed from their group upon enabling GMA as a part of SAML SSO. 

# Proposal

We need to update the current flow before removing the GMA feature flag to not remove group members from the group upon enabling GMA.

title: Record Cilium Processing Volume Usage Metrics
description:
### Problem to solve

<!-- What problem do we solve? -->
Currently we do not collect any usage ping data on Cilium usage.  We need to collect some telemetry so we can start reporting and measuring usage of this feature. * [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-analyst)

* [Allison (Application Ops)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#allison-application-ops)

Personas are described at https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/ -->

### Further details

<!-- Include use cases, benefits, and/or goals (contributes to our vision?) -->

### Proposal

<!-- How are we going to solve the problem? Try to include the user journey! https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/journeys/#user-journey -->
The following data will be collected as part of the usage ping:
* The total number of packets that Cilium has analyzed across all environments
* The total number of packets that Cilium has analyzed and found to be anomalous across all environments

### Links / references

### Implementation details

First few steps towards this were implemented:

- Prometheus query: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/30006
- Analytics counter: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/30005

We have unfinished implementation in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/30328. This MR had performance issues described in [this comment](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/214029#note_335582579). title: Update nodejs-scan dependencies to their latest versions
description:
Our [nodejs-scan analyzer](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/nodejs-scan) has a lot of dependencies, most of which have been recently updated. We need to update to the latest and greatest each of them.

Most importantly, the NodeJsScan project itself has finally released a new version ([v3.7](https://github.com/ajinabraham/NodeJsScan/releases/tag/v3.7)). This contains rule updates which we should consume and provide for our customers.

title: Update flawfinder analyzer to 2.0.11
description:
[Flawfinder version 2.0.11](https://sourceforge.net/p/flawfinder/code/ci/master/tree/ChangeLog) is now available. We should update our analyzer to take advantage of it.

### Changelog

* 2020-02-17 David A. Wheeler
	* Version 2.0.11
	* Provide a much more detailed error report, including recommended
	  solutions, when character encoding problems hit.
	  As Python3 has slowly gained in popularity, its failure to provide
	  useful built-ins to handle real-world character encoding problems
	  hurts more people. (E.g., many files don't comply with *any*
	  character set encoding standard, and Python3 can't read them
	  without enabling options that are wrong for others.)
	  We can at least provide much more detailed feedback to help
	  explain the various options available.

title: Update SpotBugs to Support Java 13-15
description:
**Update:** See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/347067+ instead for Java 17 (LTS). The [pre-compilation strategy](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/sast/#pre-compilation) remains supported for other Java versions.

We have reports that our SpotBugs instance does not support Java 13. 

We need to update our [SpotBugs scanner](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/spotbugs) to support Java 13

### Implementation Plan

- Add Java version to [`.tool-versions`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/spotbugs/-/blob/ff2b2d334edcab33bbca6bf478df78ba545cca52/config/.tool-versions#L3) file
- Add [test project ensuring support for Java version](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/spotbugs/-/blob/ff2b2d334edcab33bbca6bf478df78ba545cca52/.gitlab-ci.yml#L39)
- [Optionally] spike on providing custom `.tool-versions` file to allow workarounds for unofficially-supported java versions

title: Backend: CI_DEPLOY_* variables not set if gitlab-deploy-token is defined in group settings
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

As described [here](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/deploy_tokens/index.html#gitlab-deploy-token), you could add a special deploy token, which would be exposed as environment variables in a CI job. Doing so in a project works fine, but I need this deploy token to be valid for all projects in this group. So I added a group deploy token with the same name. Unfortunately after this change the CI_DEPLOY_USER and CI_DEPLOY_PASSWORD variables are undefined in the CI job.

### Steps to reproduce

- Add a group deploy token with name 'gitlab-deploy-token'
- Run a CI pipeline in a project within this group.

### Workaround

1. Created a deploy token in group level named `gitlab-deploy-token`
1. Set group level environment variables `CI_DEPLOY_USER` and `CI_DEPLOY_PASSWORD` to `gitlab-deploy-token` and the value thereof, respectively.

### Proposal

1. Either provide the values automatically
1. or add the workaround in the documentation

### Example Project

Example project: https://gitlab.com/justinvtime-test/test

Build with the project deploy token defined:
https://gitlab.com/justinvtime-test/test/-/jobs/505669965

Build with the group deploy token defined:
https://gitlab.com/justinvtime-test/test/-/jobs/505668102

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

the CI_DEPLOY_USER and CI_DEPLOY_PASSWORD variables are undefined in the CI job

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

the CI_DEPLOY_USER and CI_DEPLOY_PASSWORD variables are defined in the CI job

title: Remove strict naming conventions for Conan for self-managed instances
description:
### Problem to solve
The GitLab Conan Repository recipe must be the + separated project path, which can easily conflict with the 51 character restriction within Conan. We should remove this restriction for self-managed instances, so they can work more efficiently. 

### Intended users
* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)
* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)

### Further details
- We enforce strict naming conventions to prevent duplicate package names on GitLab.com, but for self-managed instances this is not a concern and something our customers are willing to manage. 

### Proposal
- Simplify naming conventions for the Conan recipe for self-managed instances.

title: Make MergeRequestMergeabilityCheckWorker idempotent
description:
That's currently running on low urgency and just for `gitlab` project and the job is already idempotent (meaning we could just set `idempotent!` at it).

Out of `329,661` jobs started and processed, [`2,956` were duplicates](https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/goto/b0fd93fc297b76dbd774123cc58a9966).

The timings there aren't great, but still acceptable for the `besteffort`:

![Screen_Shot_2020-04-09_at_11.59.25](/uploads/8476bac667d2c1f4c7e6062945530446/Screen_Shot_2020-04-09_at_11.59.25.png)

Most time as expected is spent on Gitaly:

![Screen_Shot_2020-04-09_at_12.38.52](/uploads/2ba520e7f6b1f7f49ccc66be2f1c7ed9/Screen_Shot_2020-04-09_at_12.38.52.png)

Source: https://dashboards.gitlab.net/d/sidekiq-queue-detail/sidekiq-queue-detail?orgId=1&from=now-7d&to=now&var-PROMETHEUS_DS=Global&var-environment=gprd&var-stage=main&var-queue=merge_request_mergeability_check

Considering the timings and the considerable throughput we'll see in near future, that's a potential SLI breaker.

title: Owner Converted to guest in group could view Storage Quotas
description:
**[HackerOne report #843381](https://hackerone.com/reports/843381)** by `whitehattushu` on 2020-04-08, assigned to @cmaxim:

There is a vulnerability that allows the user downgraded from Owner to Guest to view storage quotas even when user has no access

Steps To Reproduce:  
1: Start a Group with GitLab gold  
2: Add an owner to group  
3: Now login into the newly added owner account  
4: Go to Administration--->Usage Quotas and keep interceprting requests in burp until you get below request

```  
POST /api/graphql HTTP/1.1  
Host: gitlab.com  
Connection: close  
Content-Length: 800  
accept: */*  
Sec-Fetch-Dest: empty  
X-CSRF-Token:[REDACTED] 
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/80.0.3987.163 Safari/537.36  
content-type: application/json  
Origin: https://gitlab.com  
Sec-Fetch-Site: same-origin  
Sec-Fetch-Mode: cors  
Referer: https://gitlab.com/groups/sso-securty-grp/-/usage_quotas  
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate  
Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.9  
Cookie: _[REDACTED]

[{"operationName":"getStorageCounter","variables":{"fullPath":"sso-securty-grp"},"query":"query getStorageCounter($fullPath: ID!) {\n  namespace(fullPath: $fullPath) {\n    id\n    rootStorageStatistics {\n      storageSize\n      __typename\n    }\n    projects(includeSubgroups: true) {\n      edges {\n        node {\n          id\n          fullPath\n          nameWithNamespace\n          avatarUrl\n          webUrl\n          name\n          statistics {\n            commitCount\n            storageSize\n            repositorySize\n            lfsObjectsSize\n            buildArtifactsSize\n            packagesSize\n            wikiSize\n            __typename\n          }\n          __typename\n        }\n        __typename\n      }\n      __typename\n    }\n    __typename\n  }\n}\n"}]

```  
5: Once you get below request now go to main owner accout and change the permission of newly added owner to guest  
6: Now you will see that guest has no access to Storage Quotas as below attached noperm.jpg  
7: Now repeat the request you captured above  
8: You will get all storage detail of group

## Impact

Improper Access to data

## Attachments

**Warning:** Attachments received through HackerOne, please exercise caution!

[REDACTED]

<!-- triage-serverless v3 PLEASE DO NOT REMOVE THIS SECTION -->
### Main issue

This is the ~frontend part for https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/215467

### Proposal

Here's what we want to do as part of this issue:

- Extend the Security Dashboard filters to support a complex options structure in the **Report type** filter
    - The Container Scanning option will have optional child options to make it possible to filter vulnerabilities by specific scanned images
    - This should be implemented using the upcoming `GlFormCheckboxTree` component: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-ui/-/merge_requests/1269
- Properly parse API responses and format API requests to support the new JSON structure (to be agreed upon with ~backend)
    - Note: there is some work being done to switch from REST to GraphQL in the Security Dashboard which might affect how we go about addressing this issue
- Update the documentation to showcase the options nesting in the dropdown filter

![all](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/c4b7ee6062aaf9dd8a112be9ba96b4d7/all.png)

/cc @nmccorrison

title: Infinite spinner when trying to open a non-existent design
description:
### Summary

When following a deep link to the non-existent/deleted design, the infinite loading spinner is shown instead of error message

### Steps to reproduce

Try to open `https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/growth/product/-/issues/1520/designs/Usage_quota_storage_-_iteration.jpg#note_319385397` or a link with the wrong design filename. You will see an infinite spinner instead of error message

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

When opening a non-existent MR, an infinite spinner is shown

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

We should show a correct error message notifying the user about non-existent design.

This bug reproduces on GitLab.com

title: Follow-up from "Add API documentation stubs for Vulnerabilities API changes"
description:
The following discussion from !17364 should be addressed:

>>>
`doc/api/vulnerability_issue_links.md` has almost the same content as https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/issue_links.html, with the exception that `link_type` is missing. I cannot understand its relevance with vulnerabilities even after the explanation Wayne gave in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/17364#note_315617495:

> When you go to the vulnerability list and create an issue from a vulnerability, it creates an issue and a modal `vulnerabilities::issue link`. The modal links an issue to the vulnerability. We are explicitly *not* making issues dependent on vulnerabilites (nor vice-versa).

As a user, if I stumbled upon those two docs, I'd be confused. The new doc uses the same API endpoints as https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/issue_links.html, so how is it different?
>>>
